title: Before 1 October 2017, will Ban Ki-moon announce that he is running for president of South Korea?
preds: chances have become theoretical given we have just had elections
One supposes this is being kept open against the very slight chance of something happening that requires another election.  If there were a number lower than zero, I'd use it.
Dropping my last few points because he's so clearly out at this point.
Highly unlikely, even with the recent developments.
UFPOT, It's a done deal now... His NEW job's been announced: http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2017/4/7/ban-ki-moon-hks/
Updating for the passage of time. It appears even more unlikely now.
Time for him to write a book and become president of a university some place.
Elections held on May 9, 2017, and Ban Ki-moon took himself out of the running a while ago

The elections will be held on May 9. Ban dropped out of the race last month and he recently accepted a visiting professor position at Harvard University. It looks like a clear cut no, however, there is still the slightest of chances that this will change over the next few months.
The previous incumbent has significant support as it currently stands.
The elections are held within 58 days and he isn't even a candidate or the front runner so it seems extremely unlikely

Affirming.  Even if Mr. Moon changes his mind, he now has less than 60 days to make a campaign happen.  I do not believe this is logistically possible, especially given his overt bowing out when he might have had a whisker of time to do it earlier.
60 days too short to run campaign.

South Korean president Park Geun-hye forced from office by constitutional court. Opinion polls show that that Moon Jae-in, a former MP from the opposition Democratic party of Korea who lost the 2012 election to Park, is the current favourite to succeed her when South Koreans go to the polls, most likely on 9 May.
The ROK will get a new president, but Ban Ki-moon lacks the internal political power for the job.
Unlikely, but going up a little in case the Samsung scandal changes his mind.

Ban Ki-moon did announce that he would not run on Feb. 1st (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/01/world/asia/ban-ki-moon-president-south-korea.html), but given the last developments around Samsung he might change his mind...

They need political stability after the big upheaval from the scandal surrounding Park.  And also N. Korea being crazy trouble maker makes stability important.  And someone who was head of the UN has so many connections world wide, who he can call on to help put pressure on N. Korea and other relationships too, particularly China.

President Park's reputation is in tatters, dragging down the Conservatives and Mr. Ban. His decision appear to be too calculated and political, rather than principled. Probably too uninspiring as a presidential candidate with only limited political support.
I don't know anything about this at all, but I'm sticking to my first guess

He has changed his mind. Of course he might change it again, but that is unlikely.
It seems he's pulled out though it could be just a ploy to test his support.

My base rate for whether he would run or not was high at first (I guessed about 70%) because he was clearly going through the motions to run. However, he was met with poor response and lots of criticism, which perhaps led him to declare that he would stay out of domestic politics and the presidential race altogether. Thus, I adjusted the probability to 10%. However, I still think that there could be reason for him to change his mind. My final conclusion is about 12%.
I gather there is some pressure on him to reverse his decision.  There's still time to do this, but it seems unlikely.
Announced he is out of race.

After Ban's withdrawal, the pro-US conservatives seem to be at a disadvantage. 
Today's announcement that the current SK government will complete THAAD deployment this year; seems to indicate the conservative government intends to install before a change in government (unless Park is allowed to stay . - could this be the conservatives solution?).

I'm dropping down from a prior forecast of certainly, yes. I think if you'd asked Ban's camp a month ago it would have said he planned to announce by now (he met with some ruling-party politicians before they broke away---something they did in part as an effort to have him be their new party's presidential candidate) but instead of gaining momentum, Ban has lost popularity upon returning to South Korea, according to polls. I'm going to stay above 50% through the end of the month/lunar new year and drop if no announcement by then. There are recent rumblings of Ban calling for some sort of constitutional modification. Anyone know what that's about (hopefully for sake of my Brier score it's not him wanting to be prime minister instead of president).
Up from 85% since Ban seems to be plowing ahead in spite of corruption allegations against his family [1,2].

1. His bother's potential arrest will not play well to a scandal fatigued nation. 2. His polling has not increased recently for this 72 year old. 3. He is going though the motions of what it takes to run so there is a chance he will run
If he runs, the real chances that he wins are low, and he must know this.

Base rate of secretary generals running for president is quite low (29%, as indicated by pietrokc). This correlates nicely with Park's impeachment proceedings, which could leave him with only a short amount of time to act. On top of this, there is the ethical issue (UN secretary generals are not supposed to run for election immediately after their term ends), the fact that his UN record is quite poor, he doesn't have much charisma or English fluency, he doesn't have much of a support base, and his family is caught up in bribery allegations.

Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn will act as interim president; the the Constitutional Court's review of Park's impeachment before June 7 2017; if impeachment is confirmed elections can be held as soon as august 6 2017

I started work on this question being very willing to believe Ban would run. I read all the articles and read between all the lines. The consensus is quite high (65% as a write), and one of my flaws is too much eagerness to beat the consensus, so I kind of wanted to put this at 75% or 80%.

Yes.  News for at least a year has signaled the intent.  His party has about 1/3 of the legislative seats and
is fighting the current president's scandal.  He would probably run on a platform of cleaning it up, rationality,
etc.  Maybe a good move for the party, but not perhaps not convincing/ winning.  What is the reputation of other
'next in line' candidates?  Standing of other parties' (Minjoo) potential candidates?

President Park's troubles have been a major setback for Ban Ki-Moon's presidential ambitions, as it has shortened the expected time frame. However, the ruling conservative party  needs a good candidate, but so far there does not seem to be any conservative alternative other than Ban. Ban's chances are likely to improve the longer the impeachment process drags on - he has already indirectly confirmed that he is interested in the job.
https://crackdnews.blogspot.com/2016/12/ban-ki-moon-might-be-south-koreas-next.html
"Ban Ki-moon, outgoing UN Secretary General, whose second five-year term is set to end by the end of this year, reclaimed top spot in recent South Korean presidential polls. A local survey showed on Monday that out of 2,528 voters in a nationwide poll conducted by local pollster Realmeter between December 19 and 23, support for Ban as the countryâ€™s next leader was 23.3 per cent, up 2.8 percentage points from the previous week.........No competitive presidential contender was found in the ruling bloc and Ban is seen as the last remaining hope for conservative voters."

He has stepped down from the UN as Secretary General of the United Nations, and is 72 years of age. A man at his age, with his capabilities, intelligence, ambition and clout would be best served by making the lateral move to take the South Korean presidency. The situation in South Korea is so unstable and needs solid leadership and vision. Ban Ki-Moon has all of that in abundance and is most likely to bring stability to an highly volatile situation.  I mean, why step down from the UN? You don't become head of the UN without being ambitious. The situation in South Korean is the perfect opportunity for him to progress professionally and he will certainty take this opportunity with both hands.
That's a natural move to make for him
There is some room for him to try and make his comeback, now better than ever.
Yes - unpredictable politics and change continue to be themes

BKM is leaving the general secretary office soon. S. Korea, after the forced resignation of their president, is looking for a reputable candidate. BKM presents such a new, clean face that the country needs.
He is not prepared for the rough and tumble of South Korean politics.
He hasn't discussed it with family yet but will want to run

Clearly he is thinking about it and its clear from the SK media that the Korean political parties are thinking about it and the accusations of corruption have already started. I have no idea how much will stick, but Korean politics seems to be a rough game so Ban could be caught up in a big scandal and withdraw or he could just decide that he does not want to have to deal with the attacks that he seems bound to continually have to face. He does not appear to have any clear political policies or narrative to sell to voters, or to provide a compelling reason to vote for him. It seems quite common during the early stages of election campaigns for well known names to be put forward to test the waters, but unless they get strong support early they tend to disappear. So I will start at 35% and if he is still a possible in a couple of months I will reconsider.

Based on the recent hints that Ki-moon has given and the vibes that those close to him are getting outlined here: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-26/un-chief-ban-ki-moon-could-win-korean-presidency/7966090 and here: http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/10/116_215396.html, it seems that he would be likely to run... roughly 80% as a starting point. On the other hand, the fact that he is fairly old, has no recent political experience (vs diplomatic experience) and that he has been gone for 10 years sways me to lower that percentage some, because of these I would bump that percentage down to 70% Based on those points and some other varying analyses that I have run across I would about the benefit in delaying his announcement in order to stay out of the name calling, muck and mire that is associated with a political race (particularly a presidential one) and to keep his name separate from the current ruling party leader's name there would be more time to consider not running and retiring completely. Out of the last 4 secretaries general, 1 has run for president after retirement (Kurt Waldheim), and Kofi Annan was speculated to do so but did not run. So given speculation, candidates have run half of the time. There seems to be plenty of speculation on Ban, and the timing aligns nicely with the elections in Korea so I will give this another 10% bump.

Based on what I think I've gleaned of his character, as well as the existence of the UN resolution discouraging such a transition, I think it highly unlikely that he's got the desire or the guts to pursue this course of action.

Only 1 of 7 previous secretary-generals have gone on to lead their country (14.3%), going against a UN resolution that discourages this. Ban Ki-moon has made no official suggestions that he intends to run for president, and he is aware of the UN resolution. All suggestions he will are purely specualtive at the current time.

The UN resolution on retired secretary generals avoiding governmental positions “immediately on retirement” is open to some interpretation. What does immediately mean? In the past other retired SGs have run for president but it was 4 years or more after retirement. Will a December 2017 election stretch the definition of immediately? It is hard to see him passing up this opportunity if he feels he can win, that he is needed and that there would not be much backlash from the decision. He has been a lower profile SG and he may choose to delay an announcement for a few months after his retirement.

On one hand:  the UN General Assembly adopted Resolution 11(I), which states, “It is desirable that no Member should offer [a Secretary-General], at any rate immediately on retirement, any governmental position [. . .] and on his part a Secretary-General should refrain from accepting any such position.”
On the other hand, the geopolitical situation in 2017 will require skillful and respected leaders to stabilize the turmoil. 
So, I do not favor either result until Ban steps down.

This seemed likely even before the scandal implicating President Park broke http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/10/116_215396.html and it will be even more likely after now that clearly the country needs new leadership.
